question: お兄さん
userExplanation: can also be used to refer to a guy that you don't know who has a youthful appearance.
sourceMnemonic: This word starts with an <ja>お</ja> to make it more polite. Then it has the kanji <kanji><ja>兄</ja></kanji> which you already know. Lastly, it has <ja>さん</ja> which is an honorific to elevate people and be polite. This is basically the formal way of saying <vocabulary>older brother</vocabulary> (versus plain old <ja>兄</ja>). It can also be used to refer to a <vocabulary>guy</vocabulary> that you don't know who has a youthful appearance.
sourceReadingMnemonic:
The reading for this one is pretty tricky, and I'd consider it an exception. To remember it, you have to learn the <ja>兄</ja> part, and everything else will fall into place. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

Your (kind) <vocabulary>older brother</vocabulary> pushes you down on the ground. You stand up and look at your <reading>knee</reading> (<ja>にい</ja>), which is all bloody. "Why'd you do that to my knee!?" you ask. "You're supposed to be a nice older brother, that's why I call you <ja>お兄さん</ja>!"
